textRegions.text: Moving to Gerrit for Code Review
(Not shown: email notifications from GitHub and Rietveld)
good for after-the-fact or unplanned code review
no easy way to visualize progress over iterations
record of prior iterations is not permanent
Whole interface tailored to code review
No need to clutter remote repo with work in progress
Review and its entire history centralized
Rietveld is effectively an island, so easily overlooked
Performance sometimes slow and initial set-up can be painful
Mailing lists (eg. Git’s own development process, and the Linux kernel’s)
(Not shown: email notifications from GitHub and Gerrit)
Gerrit is a (highly evolved) fork of Rietveld, so it tries to preserve all of Rietveld’s advantages, while eliminating its disadvantages:
Tightly integrated in flow between team and repo; no longer an island
As GitHub is still the final destination of the code, so after-the-fact commenting and review is still possible
A radical departure from the way we currently work:
In particular, things like topic branches must be approached in a different way
Initial learning curve is a road bump
Because Gerrit is an integral part of the workflow, it makes code-review an integral part of everything we do
It is highly streamlined for its purpose (just check out those keyboard shortcuts), so it doesn’t get in the way
It will turn us all into coding ninjas
Jenkins verifies that the test suite passes and gives it a “+1 verified”
A human being reviews the patch, giving it a “+1 reviewed”
Once the patch has “+1 verified” and “+1 reviewed” it can be merged to master
Gerrit does the merge and pushes to GitHub
If you’re pairing, your pair is free to give a “+1 reviewed” to your submission as soon as it is pushed

If we’re worried about Jenkins not being fast enough to handle the volume of commits (or too flakey), there’s always the options of giving your submission a “+1 verified” yourself (ie. saying “I manually tested this)
It should also provide an incentive to us to get Buffet working, or spin up Jenkins slaves on more boxes...
Note that Gerrit won’t blindly merge and push to GitHub
Ultimately, it’s a human decision to press the “Submit” button once the review has been completed
Gerrit will send emails along the way:
What happens if you need to rush something into master right now, bypassing review?
In an emergency, you can give it the required “+1 reviewed”, and even the “+1 verified” yourself
For obvious reasons, this kind of capability should be used with discretion and caution
Gerrit expects to be the gatekeeper
If you push directly to GitHub, bypassing Gerrit, Gerrit will undo your push next time it pushes, because it will force push
To avoid unintended mistakes, we might tweak our accounts to not have push access on GitHub
If we do that, we’ll keep a few privileged accounts on hand, just in case Gerrit ever does a Skynet on us and needs to be unplugged
Set up Git hooks (for Change-Id: support)
Clone from Gerrit, making it your “origin”:
Or point an existing clone at Gerrit:
For convenience, you may still want a GitHub remote
Do everything on a topic branch
Assuming you cloned from Gerrit, your “origin” will be Gerrit, so you can push with:
Note that the explicit topic branch name is just an annotation; you can also just:
If you do provide explicit topic branch names, Gerrit will show them in a few places in the UI
Given a remote named “gerrit” with config:
Pushing to Gerrit could be done with:
Or, explicitly naming the topic branch:
You can specify default arguments to be added when pushing:
Note you can be even cleverer with custom remotes:
Sending something to Jimmy for review becomes:
You can also do it the hard way...
Code review in Gerrit is nice; the UI is almost entirely navigable by keyboard shortcuts
Just say you want to check out the code and play with it yourself, Gerrit provides some quick Git incantations for easy copy-and-pasting
Let’s say you get some feedback from your review
You make the changes and resubmit:
When you push an amended version of something already under review in Gerrit, the Change-Id allows Gerrit to recognize it
When you push a branch with multiple commits, each commit becomes a patch for review in Gerrit
Gerrit’s default submission type is “Merge If Necessary”
That means, if the HEAD has moved forward while a change is under review, it ends up producing a merge commit
This can lead to a hard-to-follow history:
* | |   3864749 Merge "Renewal email: better guards for 'friends helped the cause'"
| * | ab73860 Renewal email: better guards for 'friends helped the cause'
* | |   eff13b1 Merge "Renewal email: clean up table layouts"
| * | 0a5cff8 Renewal email: clean up table layouts
| * | fd430f9 Renewal email: switch to with_html_email_layout
* | |   481138d Merge "Renewal Email: Show friends in Cause"
| * | 764df65 Renewal Email: Show friends in Cause
Another problem is that Gerrit won’t bother trying to merge if any of the involved files have changed during the review
We fix this by turning on “Automatically resolve conflicts” in the project settings
We fix the plethora of merges by telling Gerrit to use the “Cherry Pick” submission style
Whenever a change is approved, it is cherry-picked
This gives us a basically linear history
The “Cherry Pick” style also gives us some useful automatic annotations:
Fixed oversized box overflow in IE
Some old styles in the publisher css were causing the preview box
to expand to 1000px. This was causing IE to blow up. Fixed it.
Gerrit knows when one commit depends on earlier commits
Because we’re using the “Cherry Pick” submission style, dependencies are basically ignored
If a change is approved and can be cherry-picked, Gerrit will do so regardless of its dependencies
Collaborating on someone else’s topic branch
Once their topic is pushed to Gerrit, you can fetch it:
git fetch ssh://me@gerrit.causes.com:29418/causes refs/changes/39/39/1 && git checkout FETCH_HEAD
If you plan on working on it for a while, name it:
Pushing new commits will create new patches in Gerrit, with a dependency on previous commits in the topic
Amending existing commits will create new versions of existing patches, thanks to the Change-Id
If you want you like breaking your work up into smaller commits, but don’t want to create a slew of patches in Gerrit, you can squash your topic before pushing
We’ve set up an unrestricted “staging/” namespace, which Gerrit will pass straight on to GitHub without holding for review:
If you push commits with Change-Ids through to the “staging/” namespace, Gerrit will consider those to have been “merged”
If you later push the same commits for review, Gerrit will recognize the Change-Ids, consider them already-merged and reject your push, saying “no new changes”
The workaround is to not let Gerrit see those Change-Ids when you push to staging
There is a script in our devscripts repo gerrit-stage.sh, which can be used to push a topic through to staging, stripping the Change-Ids automatically
Install the git-review script from our devscripts somewhere under your $PATH to simplify the process of uploading a topic branch for review
push a the HEAD of the current topic to refs/for/master:
push a local topic branch to refs/for/master:
You can push to a specific branch using the second parameter
The branch must already exist on the remote (for example, by creating it through the Gerrit web UI)
Regardless of whether you supply parameters, you will be prompted, with reasonable defaults
or give your topic a name which will appear in the Gerrit UI
What will this look like in practice?
will we end up working with multiple patches in a given topic?
or will we end up squashing topics into single patches?
will this encourage us to break our topics into smaller sub-topics?
Hard to say until we try it and find out what works best for us
As before, submodule changes must be pushed before superproject changes
In a system where everything gets reviewed, that means submodule changes must be reviewed before superproject changes
You can push both at the same time, but Jenkins will fail to verify the superproject changes until the submodule changes get accepted and merged
What if our experiment with Gerrit turns out to be a failure?
GitHub continues to be the canonical authority, containing all our history
We can dismantle Gerrit, set our “origins” back to GitHub and go back to our old ways...
... or try alternatives like GitHub’s pull requests
Gerrit is an exciting addition to our array of tools
It promises to substantially increase our code quality and maximize knowledge transfer and learning because it makes code-review an integral part of our daily practice
There’ll be a learning curve, but learning is fun
Install our git_hooks; the Gerrit hook has already been added
